DOC.HEAD: Eagle Nest Raises Questions About Plant Location
DOC.TEXT: Discovery of an eagle's nest apparently has complicated plans to build a $75 million hazardous waste treatment plant. A state game warden found a pair of the birds nearly finished building their nest this week in a tall pine on an 86-acre site in central Florida where Florida First Processing Inc. wants to build the plant. Bald eagles and their habitat are protected by federal and state laws, said Don Palmer, a biologist in the Jacksonville office of the federal Fish and Wildlife Service. The eagles were greeted with cheers from some of the 15 families who live a half mile from the site 10 miles south of Mulberry and bitterly oppose the plant. ``It's an answer to our prayers,'' said spokeswoman Sandra Lancaster. Because federal and state laws prohibit relocating or disturbing the endangered birds, the plant's developers could be barred from building, according to federal and state wildlife authorities. ``Obviously we have to talk with the Fish and Wildlife bureau to learn more about this,'' said Florida First vice president Ted Leigh, who was unaware of the nesting eagles until Wednesday. Federal and state guidelines say development is prohibited within a minimum of a 750-foot radius, or about 40 acres, of a nest, Palmer said. Outside that, development up to a mile radius of the nest can be restricted by federal officials.
